headline: [BREAKING] Yoruba Nation rally: Jumoke Oyeleke buried in Lagos
summarized_story:
A sachet water seller who was killed during the Yoruba Nation rally in Ojota, Lagos, Jumoke Oyeleke, has been buried today.
The PUNCH had reported that Oyeleke’s body was found during the rally held at the Gani Fawehinmi Park on July 3.
This was after security operatives stormed the venue firing teargas canisters and shooting to disperse a crowd of agitators who had gathered to demand the establishment of a Yoruba Nation.
Oyeleke was believed to have been hit by a stray bullet while security operatives shot to disperse the agitators.
However, the Lagos State Government charged a Yoruba Nation protester, Tajudeen Bakare, popularly referred to as Ogboni Chief, for the sachet water seller’s death.

headline: South-West kidnap victims paid N3bn in two years – Gani Adams
summarized_story:
THE Aare Onakakanfo of Yorubaland, Iba Gani Adams, on Thursday claimed that not less than N3bn was paid as ransom to rescue about 400 people kidnapped in the South-West in a period of two years.
Adams also lamented that over 200 persons were killed in the South-West region by the kidnappers within the years under review.
The Aare Onakakanfo said this at the fourth edition of the South-West Security Stakeholders’ Group conference held in Abeokuta, the Ogun State capital.
Adams described the conference is an opportunity to bring all security agencies together so as to enhance his capacity.
He added, “As the Aare Onakakanfo of Yorubaland, I am privy to some certain information that certain security organisations do not have.

headline: Nigerians need to pray for divine support for Police – AIG Gobum
summarized_story:
The Assistant Inspector General of Police in charge of Zone XI Command, Osogbo, comprising Oyo State and Osun State commands, AIG Mukan Joseph Gobum, has enjoined Christians to hand over command to God and also to pray for peace, progress and divine security for Nigeria.
The Zone XI police boss made this known on Wednesday during the Christian Police Fellowship of Nigeria at All Saints Protestant Chapel, Zone XI Command Headquarters, Osogbo.
He also advised officers and men of the command to shun evil and embrace righteousness adding that everyone will give account of their stewardship in this world and in life thereafter.
Elijah Olawuyi, also offered prayers for the peace of the nation and the government and the people of Oyo and Osun states.

headline: N35billion loan: Group denounces Saraki link
summarized_story:
The Kwara Consultative Stakeholders Forum, which sued the state governor, Abdulrazak AbdulRahman and others on the proposed N35billion bond/loan, has denied any connection with Dr Abubakar Bukola Saraki, a former governor of the state, in the suit.
The group, in a statement signed by its chairman, Alhaji Ayodele Olaegbe, said linking Saraki to the group is not only outrageous and demeaning but another failed effort by government propaganda machinery to deflect the general public from the issue of impropriety of the bond.
Olaegbe insisted that the group has no link, directly or indirectly, to the former Senate President or any individual or political interest.
“We also believe that the bond/loan was hurriedly approved by the State House of Assembly and didn’t go through established norms of legislative approval.
“Once a bond is sourced to carry out governance due to lack of funds, the people must be alive to participate in its process through public hearing.

headline: COVID-19: US advises Nigerians to protect elderly, chronic disease patients
summarized_story:
The United States’ Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has advised Nigerians to pay attention to the elderly and persons battling with chronic diseases as the third wave of COVID-19 spreads.
U.S. CDC Nigeria Country Director, Dr. Mary Adetinuke Boyd addressed the key stakeholders at a workshop on COVID-19 messages and presentation of information and communication materials.
She urged religious leaders to mobilize their counterparts and members to take measures to protect themselves, families and congregations, using the scriptures to buttress recommended actions.
“I encourage you to protect vulnerable members of your communities, such as the elderly and those suffering from chronic diseases,” Boyd added.
The Messages of Hope Project engages Muslim and Christian religious leaders and groups in reaching members of their communities and beyond.

headline: Infrastructure: Gov Ikpeazu to commence ‘one ward, one project initiative’ in Abia
summarized_story:
Governor Okezie Ikpeazu of Abia State has disclosed plans to commence the execution of one project in every political ward of the state as part of his “one ward, one project initiative”.
Ikpeazu dropped the hint during a meeting with the executive chairmen of the 17 local government areas of the state and councillors at the Michael Okpara Auditorium Umuahia.
He directed councillors of each ward to articulate and submit, through their respective Leaders of Council, one project that is dear to the hearts of the people of his ward.
Ikpeazu charged the chairmen to work in synergy with their deputies and councillors for greater development in their areas.
Governor Ikpeazu also implored them to sensitize and mobilize them to participate actively in the ongoing continuous voters registration exercise.

headline: Banks, state offices close for ‘Isese Day’ celebration in Osun
summarized_story:
Banks and state government offices in Osun, were closed on Friday, for the ‘Isese Day’ celebration, the News Agency of Nigeria (NAN) reports.
NAN recalls that the ‘Isese Day’ was set aside by Osun Government for Traditional Religion Worshipers/Believers, to celebrate their deities and exhibit their religion.
NAN observed that all banks in Osogbo, the Osun capital, were under lock while offices at the state government secretariat in Abere, Osogbo, were equally closed for business transactions.
The secretariats of Olorunda Local Government and Osogbo Local Government, both in Osogbo, were equally deserted, except for security men on duty.
Gboyega Oyetola on Wednesday, announced through the Osun Commissioner for Home Affairs, Alhaji Tajudeen Lawal, that Friday, Aug. 20 would be a public holiday to commemorate the 2021 ”Isese Day”.

headline: Breaking: Rude boy marriage hits rock as wife files for divorce
summarized_story:
By Christian AgadibeThe marriage between Paul Okoye aka Rude Boy, one half of the defunct music group, P-Square and his entrepreneur wife, Anita Tonye Okoye is over as the latter has filed for divorce.
Sources close to the couple disclosed that an official petition citing irreconcilable differences as the basis for divorce was filed at an Abuja court recently.
The couple got married in 2014 after dating for 10 years and they both have three beautiful children together.
The news of the couple’s impending divorce comes as a rude shock to both of their families and close friends.

headline: Atiku, Fayemi, others urge citizens to defend democracy
summarized_story:
Former Vice President Atiku Abubakar and Governor Kayode Fayemi of Ekiti have called on Nigerians to be vigilant and defend the nation’s democracy .
They made the call at the National Dialogue and Public Presentation of a book titled: “Remaking Nigeria: Sixty Years, Sixty Voices “ in Abuja, yesterday.
Abubakar, who was chairman of the occasion, called on Nigerians to defend democracy saying fixing or restructuring Nigeria would help in nation-building, adding that such would help to foster a sense of nationhood.
“When that happens, especially with fairness and justice, nation-building accelerates, however imperfectly; development and nation-building do not happen by themselves.

headline: Mohammed Fawehinmi died of COVID-19-related complications –Family
summarized_story:
By Lukman OlabiyiThe family of the late Mohammed Fawehinmi has said he died of complications from COVID-19 infection.
Fawehinmi said the family could not immediately disclose the cause of the death because they wanted the information to be based on factual medical details.
“Today, however, we are in a position to inform you that our dear brother died from COVID-19-related complications.
The Mohammed, eldest son of the late legal icon and activist, Chief Gani Fawehinmi, died at about 9a.m.

headline: PIA: Ijaw youths declare Buhari, Sylva, persona non grata in Niger Delta
summarized_story:
From Femi Folaranmi, YenagoaIjaw youths across six states of the Niger Delta region under the aegis of Ijaw Youths Council have declared President Muhamammdu Buhari who doubles as minister of petroleum and the Minister of State, Timipre Sylva, persona non grata over the Petroleum Industry Act (PIA).
It said the duo were no longer welcomed in the region for their role in the passage and signing of the Petroleum Industrial Bill (PIB) into law.
The group noted that despite the fact that the constitution guarantees the duo freedom of movement to any part of the country, they would be met with boos and jeers if they ventured into any part of the Niger Delta region for disregarding the plights and cries of the people of the region over the years.
According to him, a substantial percentage to the host communities would have helped to address the age long criminality.

headline: EXPOSED: Dollar Bribes Received By Nigeria's Senate President, Lawan, House Speaker Gbajabiamila, Other Lawmakers To Pass Controversial Petroleum Bill
summarized_story:
Nigeria's Senate President, Ahmad Lawan and the Speaker of the House of Representatives, Femi Gbajabiamila were paid in dollars (millions of naira) to ensure the passage of the controversial Petroleum Industry Bill (PIB) recently signed into law by President Muhammadu Buhari, SaharaReporters has learnt.
"Lawan was paid $2 million (N823 million) while Gbajabiamila was paid $1.5 million (N617 million) as bribes," the source said.
The Nigerian Senate recently passed the Petroleum Industry Bill approving 3 per cent for host communities despite calls from various quarters that the provisions made for host communities should be reviewed upward.
Their president, Benjamin Tamanarebi said the PIB passed by NASS was a fruitless exercise and unacceptable to the host communities.
In their July 5 meeting, governors of Nigeria’s southern states also rejected the proposed three per cent share to host communities in the Petroleum Industry Bill.

headline: BREAKING: Nigeria's Anti-graft Agency, EFCC Seals Ex-Governor Kwankwaso’s Property In Kano
summarized_story:
The Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCC) has sealed a property belonging to Senator Rabiu Kwankwaso in Kano State.
Kwankwaso, a former governor of Kano State, represented Kano Central Senatorial District in the National Assembly between 2011 and 2015.
It was learnt that the anti-graft agency had been investigating the former governor over an allegation of diversion of local government funds amounting to N3.08 billion.
SaharaReporters in July reported that a former acting chairman of the EFCC was found to have allegedly suppressed corruption cases of Kwankwaso along with some others.
Kwankwaso has also had a running battle with the current governor of Kano State, Abdullahi Ganduje and known to be a critic of Buhari's government.

headline: Bayelsa governor: Using LGAs as basis for revenue sharing unacceptable
summarized_story:
Duoye Diri, governor of Bayelsa state, has faulted the use of LGAs as a basis for revenue sharing in the country.
The event was organised by the Revenue Mobilisation Allocation and Fiscal Commission (RMAFC) in Yenagoa, the state capital, on Thursday.
Diri said the existing formula needs to be looked into, adding that the RMAFC should review some of its revenue sharing parameters in the interest of equity and fairness.
“For instance, we do not agree that you should continue to use local government areas as a basis for sharing revenues.
“We know that Rivers state has a lot of resources and connections, but our take is that the right thing should be done.

headline: Businesses on edge as COVID-19 third wave peaks
summarized_story:
Businesses could be back on the brink of scrambling for strategies to escape the weight of an economy at standstill as the surge of COVID-19 third wave brings Nigeria closer to a possible lockdown decision.
The peak of Nigeria’s third wave of Covid-19 pandemic has begun, disease experts confirm, predicting that further rise in infections should be expected in the coming days as weak compliance with preventive measures persist.
Oyewale Tomori, a professor of virology in a chat with BusinessDay wondered why many Nigerians still do not believe the COVID-19 virus is circulating in the country despite rising numbers from only one-third of the 36 states.
Caution has been thrown to the wind since governments lifted lockdown and eased activities in many sectors of the economy.
Traders reported low sales, lack of cash on hand, and challenges with sourcing as significant problems facing their business.

headline: Olu Of Warri: ‘Missing Crown Won’t Stop Coronation’ – Chief Ariyo – Nigerian Observer
summarized_story:
Share FacebookTwitterStumbleuponLinkedInPinterestWarri – With just a few days to the coronation of the 21st Olu of Warri, the Egogo of Warri Kingdom, Chief Robinson Ariyo, has said that, The missing crowns reportedly stolen from the Olu’s palace, will not affect the coronation of the Olu designate, Omoba Tsola Emiko come 21st August, 2021.
Speaking to the Nigerian Observer yesterday at the Olu’s palace in Warri, Chief Ariyo ,who is also a member of the Olu Advisory Council, said , despite the ‘stolen crowns’ the coronation will go on as smoothly as planned.
Chief Ariyo, a development expert and legal practitioner, said,“The whole idea was to frustrate the crowning process, but that won’t stop the coronation.
“As at that time, the crowns were not yet stolen ; the crowns were stolen on the 1st of of April at about 3am.
While warning mischief makers and all those involved in the sacrilegious act (crown theft) , Chief Ariyo said,“A lot of people don’t understand the way nature works.

headline: Former Governor Arrested by EFCC – Nigerian Observer
summarized_story:
Share FacebookTwitterStumbleuponLinkedInPinterestABUJA – The former Governor of Abia State, Sen. Theodore Orji has been arrested by operatives of the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission (EFCCC).
The former governor, who had for long been on the Commission’s watch list was reportedly driven back to the headquarters of the EFCC in Abuja.
The former governor who is currently senator and his sons, Chinedu and Ogbonna, has for months been under EFCC investigation for alleged misappropriation of public funds and money laundering.
The former governor is alleged to have received N500 million monthly as security vote for eight years as governor of Abia State between 2007 and 2015.
Other allegations against him concerned alleged mismanagement of N2 billion Ecological Fund and mismanagement of Sure-P funds.

headline: Coronation of Sultan in Edo: Enogie of Eyaen dissociates self, Rialto hotel from ceremony – Nigerian Observer
summarized_story:
Share FacebookTwitterStumbleuponLinkedInPinterestBENIN CITY – The Enogie of Eyaen commmunity and Chief Executive Officer of Rialto Hotel, Benin City, His Royal Highness, Dr Osazuwa Aiwerioghene Iduriase has dissociated himself and the hotel from a purported coronation ceremony of Sultan Idriss Adano as the Sultan of Shuwa Arabof Edo State.
The ceremony which has been trending in the social media for days now, was allegedly scheduled for August 21 and 22, 2021 at the Rialto Hotel.
In a statement, the Enogie said that the publication linking Rialto Hotel to the coronation ceremony was not only malicious, but also done in bad faith.
He said that those behind the said coronation ceremony actually approached him on the use of the hotel for a party which was later found to be coronation ceremony of the alleged Sultan.
He therefore warmed those planning to use Rialto Hotel for such ceremony to have a rethink.

headline: COVID-19 3rd wave: Edo records 36 new cases, readies to receive 65,020 doses of Moderna vaccines – Nigerian Observer
summarized_story:
Share FacebookTwitterStumbleuponLinkedInPinterestBENIN CITY – Edo State has recorded 36 new cases of coronavirus (COVID-19), as the government intensifies efforts to contain the third wave of the pandemic and protect citizens.
The State COVID-19 Incident Manager, Dr. Andrew Obi, disclosed this after the daily virtual meeting of the State COVID-19 Taskforce, chaired by the State governor, Mr. Godwin Obaseki.
Obi said all is set for the commencement of the second phase vaccination rollout, noting that Edo anticipates the arrival of the 65,020 doses of Moderna (mRNA) vaccines approved for the state by the National Primary Healthcare Development Agency.
According to him, “Edo, in the last 24 hours, recorded 36 new cases of coronavirus (COVID-19) and zero recoveries, with a test positivity rate of 13.8 percent and 59 percent rise in active cases.
The 36 new cases were confirmed from the 260 samples collected within the 24-hour time frame.

headline: Nigeria records eight deaths, 674 new cases of Covid-19
summarized_story:
Nigeria on Thursday recorded another eighth deaths from Covid-19, just as it recorded additional 674 new infections across 16 states and the Federal Capital Territory.
The new infection figure, according to the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), has increased the country’s infection toll to 185,267.
The FCT ranked third with 38 cases while Ogun State recorded 33 to take the fourth slot and both Akwa Ibom and Oyo States reported 32 cases each.
Edo State recorded 22 while Ekiti State reported 20 with Kwara, Delta, Bayelsa and Gombe States recording 17, 12, eight and five cases respectively.
The duo of Kaduna and Osun States reported four cases each while both Enugu and Nasarawa States also reported two cases each.

headline: Wike signs open grazing ban, VAT bills into law
summarized_story:
Rivers State governor, Nyesom Wike has signed into law a bill banning open grazing in the state.
The governor also signed into law a bill on Value Added Tax (VAT) collection.
Wike who spoke after signing the bills at the Government House, Port Harcourt maintained that the judgment of the Federal High Court on VAT has sufficiently addressed the illegality perpetrated by the Federal Inland Revenue Services (FIRS) on behalf of the federal government in the collection of tax in states.
Wike noted that when agencies of the federal government are allowed to illegally demand and collect taxes meant for states, they strangulate the states financially and turn them to be beggars.
“But we are standing on the path of history as representatives of the state to have taken the bull by the horn to challenge the illegality of the federal government through the Federal inland Revenue Services (FIRS),” Wike noted

headline: Southwest paid N3bn as ransom to killer herdsmen in 2yrs – Gani Adams
summarized_story:
The Aare Onakakanfo of Yorubaland, Iba Gani Adams, has said the Southwest region of Nigeria paid not less than N3bn as ransom to herdsmen carrying out kidnapping in the zone, noting that about 400 kidnap victims paid the sum.
Adams who spoke yesterday in Abeokuta, Ogun State, at the fourth edition of the South West Security Stakeholders Group Conference, also said over 200 lives had been lost to kidnapping in the region within the years under review.
He noted that he was always receiving first-hand information about kidnapping incidents in any part of the South West.
“As the Aare Onakakanfo of Yorubaland, I am privy to some certain information that certain security organisations do not have.
When things happen in any community, they will call my line that, ‘Aare, what can you do?,” he said.

headline: Nigeria’s unity should be negotiated – says Atiku
summarized_story:
Nigeria’s former Vice President, Alhaji Atiku Abubakar, has said Nigeria’s unity, like every relationship, is negotiable and can always be negotiated.
The was edited by Chido Onumah and published by Premium Times Books, Premium Times reported.
Speaking as the chairman of the event – during which he launched the book for N2 million – Mr Abubakar said it was “amusing” to hear people declare Nigeria’s unity as fixed, yet they do everything to “destroy the (nation’s) fragile unity,” he said.
“This is why I find it amusing when people declare Nigeria’s unity as fixed and non-negotiable, while doing everything in their power to destroy that fragile unity.
Also present at the event were Mahmud Jega, the Editor-in-chief of 21st Century Chronicle who reviewed the book; Nkoyo Toyo, Nigeria’s former ambassador to Ethiopia and the permanent representative to the African Union, Premium Times reported.

“From what we have seen today, we will engage the government and National Assembly for possible amendment or repealing of the 2020 Auto Financing Policy Act, so that the quality of purchasing can be promoted,” he said.
In his remarks, the director- general of the NADDC, Jelani Aliyu expressed satisfaction with facilities in PAN Nigeria Limited, stressing that a policy that will enable growthis essential, while assuring of maximum support.
“We are looking forward for the partnership between PAN Nigeria Limited and Cherry and we hope to work with them towards exportation of their vehicles to African countries,” he said.
In her response, the acting managing director/ chief executive officer, PAN Nigeria Limited, Taiwo Oluleye, said she sincerely wished that the government could speedily act particularly in the area of tariff review.

headline: Paul Okoye, Anita heading for divorce
summarized_story:
Nigerian singer, Paul Okoye and Anita, his wife of seven years are divorcing over irreconcilable differences.
The couple met while in the university and dated for 10 years before getting married in 2014.
News reports said Anita has filed for divorce in an Abuja High court, while also moving to the U.S. with her three children.

headline: Police lied: IMN identifies members killed in Sokoto
summarized_story:
The Islamic Movement in Nigeria, IMN, has said officers of the Sokoto State Police Command killed 3 of its members and injured 12 on Thursday.
IMN said police lied by claiming that “neither a Shi’ite member nor anybody was killed or injured,” after attacking Ashura mourners in Sokoto.
The group, however, identified Bello Muhammad Illela, Imrana Umar Yabo, and Hasan Abubakar Sokoto as the persons killed during the attack.
12 others were seriously injured and are being treated by the Islamic Movement.
There wasn’t any report of a breach of the peace by the security agents in those states, why is Sokoto different?

headline: Buhari Arrives Yola For Ahmed Joda Condolence
summarized_story:
At 10:44 a.m., President Muhammadu Buhari lands at Yola International Airport in Adamawa.
President Buhari is in the state to make a condolence visit to the family of Ahmed Joda, who served as Chairman of the Transition Committee in 2015.
The President is set to pay a visit to Adamawa’s Lamido, Mohammadu Aliu Barkin Do’s palace.
The Governor of Adamawa State, Ahmadu Fintri, his Chief of Staff, Prof Maxwell Gidado, SAN, and members of the State Executive Council have already arrived at the airport to greet the President.
Heads of the state’s security agencies are also on hand to greet the country’s most important citizen.

headline: Twitter Agrees To 7 Out Of 10 Demands – Nigerian Govt
summarized_story:

“We are not inflexible in our negotiation with Twitter because we recognise both the positive and negative aspects of social media,’’ he added.

headline: EFCC arrests Orji at Abuja Airport -NigPilot
summarized_story:
Operatives of the Economic and Financial Crimes Commission, EFCC on Thursday intercepted former Governor of Abia State, Sen. Theodore Orji at the Nnamdi Azikiwe International Airport, Abuja.
Orji was quizzed alongside his son, Chinedu, who is the Speaker of the Abia State House of Assembly.
Senator Orji and his sons, Chinedu and Ogbonna, are under investigation by the EFCC for alleged misappropriation of public funds and money laundering to the tune of N551 billion.
The ex-governor was alleged to have embezzled the N500 million monthly security vote he received for eight years as governor of Abia state between 2007 and 2015.
As confirmed by EFCC spokesman, Wilson Uwujaren, the arrest of the former governor, also borders on the allegation of mismanagement of N2bn Ecological Fund and conversion of Sure-P funds.

headline: COVID-19: Nigeria Records 674 New Cases, Eight More Deaths
summarized_story:
Nigeria on Thursday recorded 674 new cases of COVID-19 with eight more deaths, according to the latest figures released by the Nigeria Centre for Disease Control (NCDC).
The data for the day showed that Lagos recorded the highest number of infections (355), followed by Rivers with 87 cases and the Federal Capital Territory with 38 infections.
As of Friday morning, Nigeria has recorded 185,267 COVID-19 cases, and 167,923 recoveries, while 2,244 persons have died from the disease.
READ ALSO: I Will Not Exit Government As A Failure, Says BuhariMeanwhile, the Federal Government on Monday commenced the second phase of the COVID-19 vaccination as part of the drive to tackle the pandemic.
This followed the United States’ donation of over four million doses of the Moderna vaccine to the country.

headline: Obasanjo Meets Secondus, Advises Politicians On 2023 Elections
summarized_story:
Former President Olusegun Obasanjo has asked political elites and the Federal Government to prioritise the security and economy of the nation, rather than the current agitation about the 2023 general elections.
The elder statesman made the call on Thursday when he met with the National Chairman of the Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), Uche Secondus, at his residence in Abeokuta, Ogun State.
Amid the recent disagreements within the party, he is confident that the PDP is emerging stronger ahead of the forthcoming elections.
After the closed-door engagement which lasted about two hours, Obasanjo and Secondus were received at the board room of the Olusegun Obasanjo Presidential Library by members of the PDP in Ogun State.
Addressing the party faithful, they called for all hands to be on deck to rebuild the fortunes of the country.

headline: Taliban ‘Intensifying’ Search For Afghans Who Helped US – UN
summarized_story:
The Taliban is intensifying a search for people who worked with US and NATO forces, a confidential United Nations document says, despite the militants vowing no revenge against opponents.
The report — provided by the UN’s threat-assessment consultants and seen by AFP — says the group has “priority lists” of individuals it wants to arrest.
Most at risk are people who had central roles in the Afghan military, police and intelligence units, according to document.
The Taliban have been conducting “targeted door-to-door visits” of individuals they want to apprehend and their family members, the report says.
The report says the militants are “rapidly recruiting” new informers to collaborate with the Taliban regime and are expanding their lists of targets by contacting mosques and money brokers.

headline: International Oil Companies Owe NDDC $4bn, Says Akpabio
summarized_story:
Senator Godswill Akpabio says oil firms operating in the Niger Delta have defaulted in their statutory remittances to the Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) to the tune of $4 billion.
Akpabio, who is the Minister of Niger Delta Affairs, made the claim on Thursday at the weekly ministerial briefing held at the State House in Abuja.
Akpabio stressed that the Ministry of Niger Delta will take a keen interest in the implementation of the three percent Petroleum Industry Act (PIA) compensation to host communities.
Funds from the Niger Delta Ministry – which was established in 2008 with a hundred ₦200 billion – shrank to ₦19 billion in 2020 and then rose slightly to ₦24 billion in 2021.
The minister revealed that ₦10 billion – out of the allocated fund – has been dedicated to fix the East-West Road.

headline: Coach Demands improved Mentality from Junior Women Handball Team
summarized_story:
Coach of Nigeria’s Under 20 Women Handball Team, Coach Bukola Duru has laid emphasis on team work, tactical and technical discipline and diligence as a recipes for success of the team in international competitions.
The National Junior Women Handball Team are currently undergoing intensive training at the Aguiyi Ironsi Cantonment in preparation for the Africa Women Junior Handball Nations Cup in Conakry, Guinea.
A statement signed by the media assistance to the Handball Federation of Nigeria Cosmos Chukwuemeka Akisi said Coach Duru, the only female coach in the Male Category of the top tier Prudent Energy Handball Premier League, was appointed by the HFN to take charge of the National Under 20 Female Handball team in July alongside Coach Isiaka Atanda as her assistant.

headline: There’s Nothing Like Mainstream Igbo, We’re All Igbos’: Chike Ogeah on Politicking Ahead of Nigeria’s Next Presidential Election – Arise News
summarized_story:
The conversations around Nigeria’s southeastern region producing the President in 2023 will always be a recurring one.
However, there are some who are making a case for the marginalised Igbos in the south-south region.
Chike Ogeah, the Managing Director of Mac Folly Limited, operator of Lagos Marriot Hotel Ikeja, says the Oshimili-Aniocha people of Igbo extraction in oil rich Delta State do not lack the human capacity in producing the next president, but have always been marginalised and often described as not being mainstream Igbo.
Mr Ogeah, a former Commissioner of Information in Delta State told ARISE News on Friday that the Oshimili-Aniocha Igbos bore most of the brunt in the Nigerian civil war and cited the Asaba massacre that occurred on October 5, 1967, when federal troops entered the town and ransacked houses, killing civilians because “they were Biafran sympathisers.”Watch the interview for more

headline: Afghanistan: Taliban Carrying Out Door-to-Door Manhunt for Those Who Worked for NATO
summarized_story:
The Taliban have stepped up their search for people who worked for Nato forces or the previous Afghan government, a UN document has warned.
The hardline Islamist group has tried to reassure Afghans since seizing power in a lightning offensive, promising there would be “no revenge”.
The Taliban have been blocking Afghans trying to flee, with one video showing a child being handed to a US soldier.
Their victory returns the group to power 20 years on from when they were toppled in a US-led invasion.
The UN chief Antonio Guterres said the only leverage the body had over the Taliban was the militant’s desire for international recognition.

headline: Afghan Footballer Zaki Anwari Among Those Who Fell to Death from US Plane in Kabul
summarized_story:
An Afghan footballer who played for the national youth team fell to his death after trying to cling to a US plane airlifting people out of Taliban-controlled Kabul, a sports federation has said.
The General Directorate of Physical Education and Sports of Afghanistan, a government institution that worked with sporting groups, confirmed the death of Zaki Anwari in the mayhem that erupted at the airport in the capital this week.
“Anwari, like thousands of Afghan youths, wanted to leave the country but fell off a US plane and died,” the group said in a statement posted on Facebook on Thursday.
In a harrowing video from the airport on Monday, hundreds of people were seen running alongside a US Air Force plane as it gathered speed on the runway – several men desperately holding onto the side.
“Before the air crew could offload the cargo, the aircraft was surrounded by hundreds of Afghan civilians,” US Air Force spokeswoman Ann Stefanek said.

headline: Nigeria: International Oil Companies Owe Niger Delta Commission $4bn, Minister Says
summarized_story:
The Minister of Niger Delta Affairs, Senator Godswill Akpabio, has accused all international oil companies (IOCs) operating in Nigeria of being indebted to the Niger Delta Development Commission (NDDC) to the tune of $4 billion.
The former Akwa Ibom State Governor also did not hesitate to assure the people of the Niger Delta region that the on-going rehabilitation of the East West Road would be completed by government in 2022.
The federal government is owing a little bit of its own part that it should do to the NDDC.
I believe that with the audit of the commission, we will begin to offset those things working closely with the ministry of finance.
Commenting on the new Petroleum Industry Act (PIA) 2021, the Minister said the Niger Delta people are happy that President Buhari has shown commitment to their cause through the Act.

headline: NNPC Floats New Subsidiary to Oversee Refineries
summarized_story:
The Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation (NNPC) on Thursday inaugurated the board of Greenfield Refinery Limited (NGRL), a subsidiary of NNPC, to oversee the establishment and operation of new refineries.
Group Managing Director of the corporation, Mallam Mele Kyari, while swearing in the new board members in Abuja, charged them to explore all options to bring an end to the current challenge of petroleum products importation.
Kyari stated, “As a business, this is a big opportunity for us and this company’s balance sheet must change positively.
This is really a new chapter and we are committed to making it work.”The NNPC helmsman stated that all the corporation’s initiatives in the areas of new refineries, condensate refineries and equity acquisition in credible private refineries were geared towards ensuring energy and security for the country.
Listed also as members are Managing Director of the Nigerian Petroleum Development Company (NPDC), Mr. Muhammad Ali-Zarah; and Tolulope Olubommo, who is to act as Company Secretary and Legal Adviser.
